article_title: Covered California makes new push to lure the still-uninsured
article_text:
Covered California makes new push to lure the still-uninsured

Photo: Paul Chinn, The Chronicle Rich Manuzon sets up a Covered California health care coverage...

More than 2 million eligible Californians are still without medical coverage, and in its third year, the state-run marketplace for health insurance will put the emphasis on capturing a fraction of them.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Victoria Colliver
article_metadata.description: More than 2 million eligible Californians are still without medical coverage, and in its third year, the state-run marketplace for health insurance will put the emphasis on capturing a fraction of them.  Covered California, where the state’s uninsured can sign up to buy coverage, will reach out primarily to the 750,000 Californians who are eligible for federal subsidies under the Affordable Care Act.  “Those are the people we want to get across the finish line this open enrollment period,” said Peter V. Lee, executive director of Covered California.    Since its debut in October 2013, Covered California has expanded coverage to 2 million uninsured people, but officials acknowledge that they haven’t reached everyone and probably will never be able to.  To get the word out this year, Covered California is spending $29 million on advertising and has opened some 500 storefronts to offer one-on-one help with enrolling.  “This may be a period where it’s not yet embedded in the culture, but there’s not the excitement of the launch,” said Larry Levitt, a senior vice president for the Kaiser Family Foundation.  California embraced the Affordable Care Act from the get-go, becoming the first state to set up its own marketplace and website, which made for a smoother experience than in other states.  [...] last year, after hoping to sign up as many as 1.7 million members, it ended with just 1.3 million enrollees.  Since the program began, the bulk of uninsured Californians gaining coverage have done so through the expansion of the Medicaid program, the state-federal health program for the poor known here as Medi-Cal.  Covered California’s Lee hopes the agency’s benefits, which include two new carriers — UnitedHealth and upstart Oscar Insurance Corp. in Southern California — as well as new stand-alone dental coverage will help attract new enrollees.  Speaking of penalties, people who don’t have health insurance face significantly higher financial penalties than they did in the past two years, particularly the first year, when the individual fee was less than $100.
article_metadata.author.name: By Victoria Colliver
